importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article's publication, indicating when public awareness of the case emerged.
The start of federal investigation into Andrew Stanton's online activity, following a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center.
The date on which a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor attempted to contact Stanton, triggering a hostile response and further escalation of the case.
The scheduled pretrial conference date in the case.
The scheduled trial date for Andrew Stanton.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Andrew Stanton posted threatening TikTok videos, marking the timeframe of the alleged criminal activity.

keyTakeAways: A Wisconsin man, Andrew Stanton, was charged with threatening federal law enforcement agents, specifically ICE agents, through a series of TikTok videos posted between August and October 2025.
Stanton allegedly called for the killing of ICE agents, including a direct statement that if ICE shows up, they should be shot.
He also referenced the murder of conservative activist Charlie Kirk, suggesting mass shootings should be used to target federal agents, raising concerns about radicalization and online extremism.

His actions prompted federal authorities to investigate, beginning with a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center, which flagged an account linked to him seeking Israeli military location data.
Stanton refused multiple attempts by federal agents to speak with him, including a hostile text exchange with a US Customs and Border Patrol officer on September 11.
A federal judge ordered Stanton to remain in detention pending trial, indicating the seriousness of the charges.
His attorney emphasized that criminal complaints are allegations and he is presumed innocent, highlighting the importance of due process in such cases.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Stanton
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, charged with threatening federal law enforcement agents through TikTok videos.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in the case, accused of making violent threats against ICE agents via online content.

namedEntities.name: ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency responsible for immigration enforcement and border control.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The primary target of the threats in the videos, linking the case to broader national debates on immigration policy and agent safety.

namedEntities.name: Charlie Kirk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A conservative political activist who was murdered on September 10, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Stanton referenced the murder in a video, suggesting a pattern of violent retaliation against political figures, adding a layer of political extremism to the case.

namedEntities.name: Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal office that monitors suspected terrorist activity and suspicious behavior.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Initiated the investigation into Stanton’s online activity after receiving a tip about his inquiry into Israeli military locations.

namedEntities.name: US Customs and Border Patrol
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal agency within DHS that oversees border security and immigration enforcement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A specific federal law enforcement body that had a direct interaction with Stanton, escalating tensions and prompting further action.

namedEntities.name: TikTok
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media platform where users share short-form video content.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The platform used by Stanton to post threatening videos, highlighting the role of social media in spreading extremist rhetoric.

namedEntities.name: Federal Prosecutors
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Officials from the U.S. Department of Justice who brought charges against Andrew Stanton.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They filed the criminal complaint outlining the allegations against Stanton, forming the legal basis of the case.

namedEntities.name: John Bradley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Stanton’s attorney, who responded to the case with a statement emphasizing the presumption of innocence.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His role in defending Stanton underscores the legal and procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Andrew Stanton, a 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, has been charged with making threats against federal immigration agents through a series of TikTok videos posted between August and October 2025. Prosecutors allege that in those videos, Stanton explicitly called for the killing of ICE agents, including a statement that if they appear in a neighborhood, they should be shot. He also referenced the murder of conservative activist Charlie Kirk, suggesting mass shootings should be carried out against federal agents. The investigation began after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center, which flagged Stanton’s request for information about Israeli military locations. Federal agents attempted multiple contacts with Stanton, including a hostile exchange with a US Customs and Border Patrol officer on September 11. Stanton has pleaded not guilty and remains in detention pending trial, with a pretrial conference scheduled for December 1 and a trial set for December 15, 2025.
title: Wisconsin man charged after posting TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents, prosecutors say
